name: Rotarized
description: Shafts, Cranks, and gears, these are at the core of the machines of modern times and it's more important then that time to learn how to put those machines together. Join us as we explore the rotarized world

quests.name: Getting screwed
quests.description: Have you never found yourself putting up shelves in the middle of the night? Well this little device might not quite be sonic but it will be fantastic for reogranizing things.

tasks.longDescription: The screwdriver is the most basic and important tool that you will find when working with these HSLA steel machines. It will allow you to change their direction, or even change how they function. So keep this little thing handy.

quests.name: An Ogre made me do it
quests.description: To get started in the world of spinning and mechanical tomfoolery, it's best to start to work on the very basics of being able to make everything else don't you agree?

tasks.longDescription: Before you get started in full you're going to need a few items to help you along the way. These are reagents that you're going to be adding to a blast furance. So head out into the world and collect a few
Outside of just reagents you're going to need something else for your setup, this will end up getting placed under the blast furnace once you've made it.

Made with stone bricks and a bit of redstone the blast furnace is actually a fairly simple recipie but it will allow you to continue through the rest of your rotarized adventure in a most painless manner

quests.name: High Strengh Low Alloy
quests.description: So now that you have your furnace setup soemwhere nice, the next step is to actually start making the steel that we've been talking about. So throw some iron in there along with your reagents
prerequisites: An Ogre made me do it

tasks.longDescription: HSLA Steel (Don't worry we didn't know what it stood for either) will become the basis of your operation when it comes to rotaraized parts. With it everything else is possible and you're going to need a lot of it. As a heads up it takes a long while for the furnace to actually heat up

HSLA Steel much like the steel produced in other similar processes can be used for regular things as well, including the creation of a pickaxe. There's nothing too special about the pickaxe itself outside of being slightly more durable then it's iron counterpart
Finally you can also craft pieces of armor, they have the same approximate armor rating as their Iron counterparts, but again have a higher durability.

quests.name: The Assembly Room
quests.description: All of this is fantastic and great, but you're going to need a place to build it and a normal crafting bench just won't do the job. Instead we're going to need to rely upon the workstable

tasks.longDescription: The worktable isn't to tough to make, instead being made from Redstone, an existing workbench, A brick, some HSLA steel and slabs. It will be the device upon which virtually all constructed machines are built.

quests.name: Part: Part 1
quests.description: The following are going to be a string of quest that have you create the most basic parts needed to construct everything else.

tasks.longDescription: The gear is the most basic component that one can think of when they are dealing with these rotarized parts. Creating one is simple, simply place 5 HSLA steel in the crafting bench in a cross like formation.

Another core item on the linuep, the Shaft is what will be used for almost any and every instance of where you need to move around power. Crafing is simple as well, simply use 3 HSLA steel in a diagonal direction on the crafting square
The next invention is of course the panel, which again is used in a wide variety of recipies and is fairly simple to craft not unlike a slab made of any other material

quests.name: My First Engine
quests.description: Alright so you've started getting yourself together, you've learned to make a few parts but what about making something with all these parts? Well then it's time to make your first engine.

tasks.longDescription: The DC Engine is fairly simple to construct but more importantly then that it provides just enough power to run a pump and a few other items. So it is a great but simple start to your path.

quests.name: Pump it up!
quests.description: One thing that you'll always find yourself needing when you're making new and fantastical devices is a liquid to put into it. We're going to teach you what you need to make to do just that

tasks.longDescription: Alright look, we can teach you how to make a pump but what good is that going to do you if you don't have a pipe to put it in? Crafted with HSLA Steel and Glass this little pipe is perfect for getting water from point A. to Point B

The Pump itself doesn't require much in terms of power. A simple DC engine can run the device although a more powerful engine could run the pump faster, which is something you might which to keep in mind for bigger projects.

quests.name: The Windy City
quests.description: The DC engine is good for getting you through the day, but like any proper machinest you're probably looking for a better solution to your problems already. Why not call upon the infinite, renwable power of the wind?

tasks.longDescription: Before you can get started you're going to want to make yourself a propeller, these aren't actually all that difficult. Just needing some steel, a shaft, and a base panel.
The next item you should find can be constructed from parts you've already dabbled in. The hub has a lot of values, but here it's going to serve as the hub of our windy operations!

The Wind Turbine is an item that can be a bit tough to work with. First to be at full power it must be at or above Y = 128. In addition to this, the area in front of the fan must be clear for at least 16 blocks or it won't produce the proper amount of power.

quests.name: Part: Part 2
quests.description: This is a continuation of your little adventure into the world of part creation, again requiring nothing more then HSLA steel for the time being.

tasks.longDescription: Made with the Shaft units that you constructed in the last part of this little adventure as well as a single piece of HSLA steel in a diagnol shape on the crafting bench, this little item is fantastic for making your eventual mounts
The Ball bearing is crafed by putting 4 HSLA steel in 2x2 shape. It will make 16 of them, which is useful, but they tend to be an ingredient for other parts rather then a part themselves.
The Shaft bearing has some limited uses, but important ones. It is crafted by surrounding a piece of HSLA steel with some ball bearings.

quests.name: It's getting steamy in here
quests.description: So the DC Engine is great and all, but let's assume that you want even more powerful for the fantastical devices that you intend to create. Then it's time to learn about turning steam into Torque, power, and speed.

tasks.longDescription: The Steam engine is a little more complicated in it's construction, and you're probably going to want to put a piece of netherrack, or something that will burn reliabably underneath it to start powering it. Simply attach it to some water in the back and make sure there's a flame underneath it.

quests.name: Part: Part 3
quests.description: This is part of the continuning discovery documentary: Parts and what they're used for. My name is David Attnborough and here we can see the rear coupling of a condenser and an impeller

tasks.longDescription: Made with those liquid pipes you were discovering earlier and some HSLA steel, the Condenser has some limited uses but the most obvious of which will be in the creation of a steam engine.
The impeller is a simple device crafted by surrounding a gear with HSLA steel bars. This device has a wide range of uses and if you were going to start making a few it might be good to keep around.

quests.name: Moving Power - Chapter 1
quests.description: The next step along your journey is going to be getting all this power you're making with your various engines around the world like you would like. It's time to meet the methods for doing that

tasks.longDescription: The wood shaft is the most basic version and it comes with it's own flaws. There is a limited amount of power that it can run through the system, but at the same time it is the cheapest in terms of resources.

The stone shaft is much like it's brother in that it isn't quite the best shaft on the market that you can buy, but it's not the worst either. Requiring a few more resources then it's wooden counterpart the Stone shaft can transport a bit more power before it just explodes

Who doesn't love a bit of aliteration in the morning? The answer is of course noone not needing necessary nerdy nacelles. Hush you it doesn't have to make sense, but the Steel Shaft does. It's the steel standard if you will for transporting your various rotational energies from one point to another.

quests.name: Part: Part 4
quests.description: As you learn more about rotarizing your world it should grow increasingly apparent you're going to need more complicated parts to compose it. It's time to meet one of the most common parts in your arsenal.

tasks.longDescription: The mount is a device that will get used in virtually all of your shafts for getting power from point a to point b. It is a crucial recipie to get used to because you'll probably be making more then your fair share of them.
Though it has a very limited application the Wyrm gear can help in the construction of a device to convert speed and power into torque a bit inneffectively. Still it's important to know these things.

quests.name: No not the dating app
quests.description: There comes a time in every man, woman, and child's life when they look upon their inventory of metals and think to themsleves "This isn't enough" it is during those times that we invent the grinder.

tasks.longDescription: The Grinder is a device that requires at least a fair amount of power and in return it will crush the ore you feed it into a more particulate matter, in fact it may turn it into two of that particulate manner, each which reward you with a bar of what you were looking for.

quests.name: Just a bit of Friction
quests.description: One of the most traditional ways for making something hotter was to rub two sticks together, well we're taking that technology to the next level with the friction heater, which every home should have.

tasks.description: You rub me the right way
tasks.longDescription: When attached to the side of a Furnance the Friction heater can use power, torque, and speed provided by an engine of some kind to help make heating up things in the furnace a bit faster and without the need for fuel.

If you've ever gone into your own tree cutting industry you know there's know fun in having to cut them down yourself. It's time to meet the woodcutter, a fantastic device for felling a tree in your tree farm setups.

Requiring not that much in terms of parts or pieces, the item vaccum will use just a hint of power to bring in nearby items to it's own inventory. So say if you wanted to collect the wood from your woodcutter... or maybe the saplings.

quests.name: Cooking up differently
quests.description: HSLA Steel isn't actually the only thing that your new fancy furnace can cook up. In fact it has a few other tricks up it's sleeve.
prerequisites: An Ogre made me do it

tasks.longDescription: This paticular recipie has a much simpler calling. The only requirement is to throw some coal into the furnance and make sure it is at at least 400 Degrees. No additives required
This set of seemingly wound up steel can be gotten by heating up your furnance even more (You might have to find some things further down the line) and adding coal coke and redstone as additives.
